title: Man got lost wallet back thanks to 1p bank transfers from good Samaritan
text:
Tim Cameron lost his wallet while cycling home from work (Picture: Kennedy News and Media)

A man has been reunited with his lost wallet after a good Samaritan contacted him by transferring 4p to his bank account.

Tim Cameron, 30, was cycling home from work when his wallet fell out his back pocket on Monday October 14.

After retracing his 5km journey, he later spotted he had received four ‘faster payments’ in his bank account – each containing part of a message.

Put together, the sequence of words read: ‘Hi, I found your wallet in the road’, gave a phone number and ended with: ‘Text or call!’

Tim then rang the number and spoke to Simon Byford, 30, who had been cycling the same route and seen the fallen wallet lying in the road.

There were four transfers of 1p in his bank account (Picture: Kennedy News and Media) The product manager, from Highbury, London, then hopped on his bike and cycled to Simon’s house the same night, picking him up a bottle of wine on the way as a thank you.

He said of losing his wallet: ‘I thought “damn, this is going to be a lot of work to sort out”. It had my UK Biometric Residence Permit and all my bank cards.

‘I didn’t have much identifying info in there so a good Samaritan got in touch with me via my bank account.

‘I thought Simon was a bloody legend. He’s the nicest bloke ever – it’s not surprising he went above and beyond to get it back to me.’

Software engineer Simon said the wallet had already been run over a few times before he managed to pick it up.

He cycled to Simon’s and got the wallet in the same night he lost it (Picture: Kennedy News and Media) He tried to contact Tim on Facebook, but could not find his account due to the common nature of his name.

After considering the ‘puzzle’ of finding the wallet’s owner, he considered the bank transfers a ‘long shot’ and was shocked when he got a phone call just an hour later.

Simon said: ‘When he got in touch I just felt surprise and delight. I was expecting him to eventually but it all happened quite quickly.’

He added: ‘If I lost my wallet in the road I would want someone to do the same. It was also just a bit of a puzzle – like how do I contact this dude who I have such little information about?

‘It was an interesting thing to ponder.’

Simon Byford received a bottle of wine for his trouble (Picture: Kennedy News and Media) Tim shared a picture of the messages sent to his bank account on Twitter, and has since racked up more than 23,000 retweets and 133,000 likes.

He confirmed to his followers that he had not yet paid Simon back the 4p.

description: Tim Cameron, 30, lost his wallet while cycling home but soon realised he'd been transferred 1p four times with a message saying it was safe.
